And double tap the Subscription Tab button to reset back top level/the full list of subscriptions showing tags/groups. ### Why should this be added? As a long time AntennaPod user, I became used to the Side-panel Subscription list. This list when organized by Tags/Groups these groups stayed open thus saving the users from having to re-navigate (open panel, open tag). I think that adding the requested feature will bring that ease of multi-tasking podcast management that the side-panel navigation experienced offers to the modern Bottom Navigation experience. I have my Bottom Navigation set as followed: Home - Queue - Subscription - Episodes - More Centering the AntennaPod experience on Subscription Tab where users have several podcast subscription organized by Tags/Groups. Open a group, do some podcast management, then navigate to Queue to make some arrangement. Selecting Subscription Tab again, this resets its location back to the top level showing all subscriptions and tag/groups. It would be best if the Subscription Tab remembers the last location it was left it at before selecting another tab like Queue or Episodes. This would make the user experience more multitasking accessible. User can navigate between Subscription, Queue, episodes to setup their podcasts listening experience. Organize The queue, go over your subscription under the subscription tab and keep up with new episodes and ongoing listens via Episodes. If and when the user needs to once again access the full list of subscriptions tags/groups, double tab the Subscription Tab. ### Screenshots / Drawings / Technical details | ℹ️ | **Implementation instructions**| |---|:---| | | This request has been discussed further below. title: Downloading/queing a single podcast (only one, for later listening) is very cumbersome/hard (UX)
body:
### Checklist

- [X] I have used the search function for [**OPEN**](https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/issues) issues to see if someone else has already submitted the same feature request.
- [X] I have **also** used the search function for [**CLOSED**](https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aclosed) issues to see if the feature was already implemented and is just waiting to be released, or if the feature was rejected.
- [X] I will describe the problem with as much detail as possible.
- [X] This request contains only one single feature, **not** a list of multiple (related) features.

### App version

3.4.1f

### Where did you get the app from

F-Droid

### Feature or improvement you want

I want to easily add/download a single podcast instead of subscribing to a whole podcast series (and download this one podcast respectively add it to my listening queue or similar). Ideally, i want two ways:
* via the GUI as usually, just without having to subscribe first
* via an URL (yeah, I know this may technically be more advanced) 
* maybe accept such an URL as a sharing target in Android and get the podcast including episode from there 
* optionally, even opening an URL would be awesome (though yet again AFAIK with Android this is impossible, as you need to register for specific URLs)

### Why should this be added?

Okay, full (user) story:
1. Let's say a friend, let Peter be his name, send me a cool link to an interesting podcast, he had listened to. it's: https://www.deutschlandfunk.de/klimaklage-2-0-warum-buerger-wieder-vors-bundesverfassungsgericht-ziehen-dlf-ff0bb7c7-100.html
2. Now, I don't want to listen to it, I want to listen to it later. I could store it in my browser open tabs/bookmarks/history, third-party software/apps/services like Pocket or so, or… as the most obvious choice and for various reasons best may be: I want to store it in AntennaPod and listen to it (later). Reasons could be:
  * hard to loose
  * I already use the app
  * cannot accidentally close tabs
  * does not get lost in tab
  * uses FLOSS app
  * …
3. Anyway, I have the website opened in my browser (Firefox for Android), so what can I do now? The question I am usually pondering about is: **How do I get that podcast episode into AntennaPod?** Ideally, I'd like to:
  * either use the "Open in app" feature to open it in the app (actually, this could have skipped the browser before, if AntennaPod can display a podcast directly)
  * or via the "Share" menu in the same way
  * or… okay… maybe "manually"
4. So, as I only have the manual option currently, my steps are:
  1. Find out how the podcast is named on the website. For my example Deutschlandfunk, I need to click on "Abbonieren" and there I can see it. (To find this out is also a thing you need to learn/know first… and obviously depends on the website, it may be actually impossible; e.g. if someone shared you a direct link to an MP3 file).
  In my example the name is "Hintergrund".
  2. Surprisingly, it works and I can find it (steps are: Open AntennaPod -> Search icon -> type "Hintergrund" -> (Enter is optional?) -> Click "Search online") – such a generic term as this one could have been missed:
  ![Screenshot_20240919-024250](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3f2dfc1e-15d4-4ee0-8d85-8e3ff5cc5171)
  3. Now, i tap on it. Actually, I now would need to find the episode. For this, I would need to scroll until I find the correct one. Maybe looking up the date on the website (by going back to it etc.) would be helpful for that, yet again this is another step.
  **Side-note:** A search function here could help/simplify this a lot!
  4.  In case I find it: I can tap on it. However, the only button besides the description I see is: "Preview". I don't want a preview though, but want to potentially download it and listen it later etc., as already explained. This works if you want to hear it right-away, but really – if I'd wanted this, I could have just used my browser and would not have gone through this "complicated" process I am describing…

I skipped one fact: At 3. you can take another way (**workaround**:):
4. Instead of searching directly (which I would intuitively do, if I am not interested in the whole podcast, which occasionally happens), I maybe already know, I need to click on "Subscribe" first.
5. Having done that, I get a bigger episode list, which is fine. There I can search, which is also fine.
6. So I find my episode and I can download it.
7. But, yet again, say I don't like the podcast in general (again many reasons could be added here: too many episodes, it's outdated and I found a very old but interesting episode, I just don't like the general content/people in there – maybe that one episode was special; or I am generally not interested in the topic, except the one that was shared to me etc.), so – naturally – I remove the podcast again.
   This warns me, that this will also remove my episodes, so now I am stuck:
   Either I keep being subscribed to the podcast I don't actually wanted to subscribe _or_ I can listen to the podcast. Or I'd would have to remember this and unsubscribe the podcast again after listening that one episode hmm… kinda bad. (Especially bad if you have auto-dowloading enabled for all podcasts BTW, as that would download episodes you never wanted to listen, then…)

### Screenshots / Drawings / Technical details

Nudging people to subscribe to a podcast could be a naive explanation for this. I bet this was not your intention and it's just because of technical issues (as indicated already), but I am also not sure whether cooperate podcast players maybe follow that pattern. Anyway, we don't want it, IMHO, we can do better! As such, support for **playing/downloading a single podcast** would be awesome!

So IMHO this is a big UX issue and missed use case.

Technically / ideas for solutions:
* Next to "Preview" could be a simple "Download" button and the issue would likely be solved already. Though I see that this view was likely not intended for listening at all…
* Maybe a bigger UI design would be to have a view for _one_ podcast episode actually. This could be opened with a tap on it and you could download it there or do whatever.
* If downloaded, the episode could just be shown as a single entry as if the podcast has been subscribed to. However, it obviously should not and it may actually auto-delete or so if the episode is listened to (though that may be configurable).
* Even if that is implemented a better "podcast preview" screen would be needed with search functions or whatever. After all, why not actually re-use the "normal" podcast screen, where you can see your episodes, if you have already subscribed? Just indicate somehow you are not subscribed, e.g. by adding a big "Subscribe" button at the top? IMHO, this would be a quite seamless integration _and_ you would have more screen space/design for the actual podcast listing (and all features like search etc. for it).
* the link limitation for opening an arbitrary URL could be circumvented by using/[creating](https://extensionworkshop.com/) a special (very little) [addon/extension for Firefox for Android](https://addons.mozilla.org/android/) that just converts the URL, if it finds a podcast (RSS feed or so?) into a canonical link or at least one AntennaPod has registered. This could be e.g. some URL like https://redirect.antennapod.org/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.deutschlandfunk.de%2Fklimaklage-2-0-warum-buerger-wieder-vors-bundesverfassungsgericht-ziehen-dlf-ff0bb7c7-100.html or custom URI like `antennapod:https%3A%2F%2Fwww.deutschlandfunk.de…` (if Android supports that) or whatever.
  URL would have the advantage you could show a fallback webpage at the subdomain, so if that link should get shared to other people, you can show them a landing page for AntennaPod (nudging them to install it :wink: ) and with a friendly link to the podcast actually shared.

title: Support for comments based on ActivityPub (`podcast:socialInteract`)
body:
### Checklist

- [X] I have used the search function for [**OPEN**](https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/issues) issues to see if someone else has already submitted the same feature request.
- [X] I have **also** used the search function for [**CLOSED**](https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aclosed) issues to see if the feature was already implemented and is just waiting to be released, or if the feature was rejected.
- [X] I will describe the problem with as much detail as possible.
- [X] This request contains only one single feature, **not** a list of multiple (related) features.

### App version

3.3.2

### Where did you get the app from

Google Play

### Problem you may be having, or feature you want

I would like be able to comments on podcast episodes and also see and reply to existing comments on podcast episodes.

### Suggested solution

There are some existing support for comments on RSS 2.0[^rss20-comments] and RSS extension namespaces (reference needed). Most recently, the _Podcasting 2.0_ `podcast` namespace introduced the tag `podcast:socialInteract`[^podcast-socialInteract]. Among other things, the main function of this tag is to enable support for distributed comments for episodes through the ActivityPub protocol. This enables listeners to comment on episodes from any ActivityPub enabled instance, such as _Mastodon_ instances, meaning that podcast comments will be part of the so called Fediverse (https://fediverse.info/, https://axbom.com/fediverse/).

AntennaPod could use this to show comments for podcast episodes and also allow, with different functional degrees, that users would also author comments and reply to existing comments.

### Screenshots / Drawings / Technical details

## Screenshots

Comments shown on podcastindex.org for one of the episodes of the Podcasting 2.0 podcast:
![image](https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/assets/260113/64c087b8-159d-4fb7-8637-c3980ac071a1)

Comments shown on Podverse for one of the episodes of the Podcasting 2.0 podcast:
![image](https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/assets/260113/53be3fd0-9d7e-427b-b4cc-cc2f0c3bce83)

## Technical Details

The XML tag `podcasting:socialInteract` [^podcast-socialInteract] can be used under the RSS `<item>` tag as in the example:
```xml
<podcast:socialInteract 
        uri="https://podcastindex.social/web/@dave/108013847520053258" 
        protocol="activitypub"
/>
```

Although there are other protocols that can be used, `activitypub` indicates that the URL indicated on the `uri` parameter points to an ActivityPub _Activity_, usually a _Note_. This _Activity_ is considered a _root comment_, and all the other comments will be either replies to this comment, or replies to replies, forming a (possibly deep) tree.

**A brief word on ActivityPub**: It provides two **APIs**, a Client to Server (C2S) one and a Server to Server (S2S) one. The S2S one is predominantly more mature in the ecosystem, as it is required for interoperability between servers. The C2S is far less mature and, in certain aspects, underspecified.  The interoperability between Clients and Servers often falls back to the [Mastodon API](https://docs.joinmastodon.org/api/). Nevertheless, a combination of ActivityPub C2S and Mastodon APIs is currently the only known way in use to generally fetch comments for a cross-app comments. 

### Fetching the comments

To fetch comments, one can fetch the _Activity_ url of the _root post_, with the header `Accept: application/ld+json; profile="https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams"`. Here is an example of a response body:

```json
{
  "@context": [
    "https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams",
    {
      "ostatus": "http://ostatus.org#",
      "atomUri": "ostatus:atomUri",
      "inReplyToAtomUri": "ostatus:inReplyToAtomUri",
      "conversation": "ostatus:conversation",
      "sensitive": "as:sensitive",
      "toot": "http://joinmastodon.org/ns#",
      "votersCount": "toot:votersCount"
    }
  ],
  "id": "https://podcastindex.social/users/dave/statuses/110634382833124876",
  "type": "Note",
  "summary": null,
  "inReplyTo": null,
  "published": "2023-06-30T17:38:30Z",
  "url": "https://podcastindex.social/@dave/110634382833124876",
  "attributedTo": "https://podcastindex.social/users/dave",
  "to": [
    "https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#Public"
  ],
  "cc": [
    "https://podcastindex.social/users/dave/followers"
  ],
  "sensitive": false,
  "atomUri": "https://podcastindex.social/users/dave/statuses/110634382833124876",
  "inReplyToAtomUri": null,
  "conversation": "tag:podcastindex.social,2023-06-30:objectId=7365466:objectType=Conversation",
  "content": "<omitted>",
  "contentMap": {
    "en": "<omitted>"
  },
  "attachment": [],
  "tag": [],
  "replies": {
    "id": "https://podcastindex.social/users/dave/statuses/110634382833124876/replies",
    "type": "Collection",
    "first": {
      "type": "CollectionPage",
      "next": "https://podcastindex.social/users/dave/statuses/110634382833124876/replies?only_other_accounts=true&page=true",
      "partOf": "https://podcastindex.social/users/dave/statuses/110634382833124876/replies",
      "items": []
    }
  }
}
```

Fetching the `replies` recursively, it is possible to build the full tree of comments.
The comments are public and do not require authentication.

**Known quirks:**
- _Pleroma_ does not return replies with the AP C2S API, but it does with the Mastodon API[^pleroma-empty-replies-issue-3061]
- Older versions of _Mastodon_ will "loop" around the responses, so it is necessary to have a stop criteria when it starts a new loop (back again to the first item)[^mastodon-replies-issue-12442]

### References

- example feed - https://feeds.podcastindex.org/pc20.xml
- `podcasting:socialInteract` tag specification - https://github.com/Podcastindex-org/podcast-namespace/blob/main/docs/1.0.md#social-interact
- ActivityPub W3C Recommendation - https://www.w3.org/TR/activitypub/
- Activity Vocabulary W3C Recommendation - https://www.w3.org/TR/activitystreams-vocabulary/
- https://activitypub.rocks/
    - https://socialhub.activitypub.rocks/
        - https://socialhub.activitypub.rocks/
- https://github.com/Podcastindex-org/podcast-namespace/discussions/623 
- https://github.com/podStation/podStation/issues/304 - research notes for the eventual implementation of this feature in podStation
- https://www.npmjs.com/package/threadcap - a Javascript package that implements the logic for fetching comments, including several needed workarounds due to the current limitations to Client to Server (C2S) implementations of ActivityPub

<!-- footnotes -->
[^rss20-comments]: Embeddable comments defined in RSS 2.0: https://www.rssboard.org/rss-weblog-comments-use-case
[^podcast-socialInteract]: `podcasting:socialInteract` tag specification - https://github.com/Podcastindex-org/podcast-namespace/blob/main/docs/1.0.md#social-interact
[^mastodon-replies-issue-12442]: Mastodon issue https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/issues/17442 (list item 4 describes the infinite loop)
[^pleroma-empty-replies-issue-3061]: Pleroma issue about empty replies on ActivityPub C2S API Chttps://git.pleroma.social/pleroma/pleroma/-/issues/3061

# Current (as per #1241)

![cleanup_settings](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5216560/10257690/df66355e-6926-11e5-9ff2-75c2ad425fc3.png)
# Enhencement

A bit more flexibility in these settings could be nice:

**Remove episodes:**
- After: [radio buttons]
  - completing playback [default]
  - pausing(/skipping) or completing playback
- With a delay of: [dropdown]
  - 0 days (immediately)
  - 1 day [default]
  - 3 days 
  - 5 days
  - 7 days
- But exclude: [checkboxes]
  - favourites [default: Y]
  - episodes in the queue [default: Y]

**What if you just pause and want to listen to an episode later again?**
Because many people just pause an episode with the intention to listen to it again later, this option should not be the default. In practice, this setting I imagine will almost always be applied in combination with a delay of a couple of days; when the episode has not been restarted after those days, there's probably a lack of interest (this would be my use case, with a setting of 5 days).

**inspiration**
Use-case of @charlesay in #1262.

title: Streaming to dlna/upnp devices (proof of concept available)
body:
I would welcome a feature to stream podcasts to dlna/upnp media renderers (cf. #280). I have implemented a proof of concept for such afeature using the cling library. (Personally, I don't consume any video podcasts and I didn't not care about them in my current implementation.) It took me a while from the first attempt, so my implementation is based on a somewhat outdated version of AntennaPod. I encourage you to have a look at it: https://github.com/volhol/AntennaPod/tree/streammedia

On the MediaplayerActivity you can find a new Item in the menu called select media renderer. 

![menu](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11587858/8340733/92a87240-1ac0-11e5-9dad-64fe018aba4a.PNG)

The app tries to find all suitable medai renderers in your local network. Just select one. The app then attemps to play the current media item form the current position on the chosen media renderer.

![select media renderer](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11587858/8340740/9c055b14-1ac0-11e5-96f0-ee32210acc74.PNG)

In fact, the app does currently not stream the content to the device itself. Instead it transmits the original URL to the device and asks it to stream the content from there. It may take a while before you can start playback. During this time, you see that the play/pause button changes appearance. Sometimes you may have to press the play button two to three time before the playback starts. Once the media item is played back on the media renderer, you can change the current position as well as the volume like you would in local mode. (Altering the volume works from the MediaplayerActivity only.)  The fast torward/reqind button disapppear since there is no suitable feature for this in dlna/upnp.

I have tested this feature on the four dlna/upnp media renderers I have access to. I found out that each of them behaves a bit differently. Thus, it may not work properly on your devices.

I am of course open to any discussion on if and how this feature could be integrated with an AntennaPod release (standard feature, separate module as prestissimo, ...). I tried to isolate most changes in separate files. Please be aware that the cling library (http://4thline.org/projects/cling/) requires at least API 15.

title: Swipe episodes away
body:
This suggestion is included in a couple other issues (e.g. #125) but I think it's worth having its own issue.

Now that episodes are added to the waiting list and the playing queue automatically, we need an easy way to dismiss the ones that don't interest us. Swiping away is the quickest and handiest way, and the one many Google apps (e.g. Gmail) are favouring:

![Swipe](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/244618/0d5d9a26-8a6b-11e2-9b03-788207dcea61.png)

![Swipe2](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/244621/1110244a-8a6b-11e2-9332-d8332db43f23.png)

The user would just have to flick their finger to the left or right, and the episode is dismissed. Unlistened episodes (that is, those the user never even started listening) would be deleted and forgotten, and listened ones (even partially listened ones) would be skipped and go to the History.

It could even be used at the top of the queue (that is, on the current episode) to skip the current episode and start listening to the next one, which would be an easy way to implement Skip without having to use extra buttons or UI elements.

title: Use a dropdown instead of tabs
body:
Here's a couple mockups of AntennaPod if it used a dropdown to move between sections instead of tabs:

![Dropdown](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/244538/7dcedcc8-8a68-11e2-93a1-4ab5c43ddf8d.png)

![Dropdown2](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/244563/55e5cf68-8a69-11e2-8c70-b5b0bbce67fe.png)

I have several reasons to think that this would be better than we have now:
- First, it would save space. Once you have subscribed to the desired podcasts (and once auto-download and auto-enqueue are implemented) the user shouldn't really have a lot of reasons to switch between sections. He will probably spend most of the time in the Episodes section, so I think that the saved space will become more important than being able to change sections quickly.
- Second, it would allow to move the History section into the dropdown. Which, being a section and not an action, I think would make more sense than having it inside the overflow menu.
- Third and most important, it would allow to swipe episodes away. Unwanted episodes could be dismissed very quickly, with the flick of a finger. Which will become very important once new episodes are added automatically to the waiting list. It's important to note that swiping away is impossible with the current approach because horizontal movement just changes sections.

title: Simplify the long-press menu
body:
This issue is related to #116 because it implies the workflow suggested there.

When you long-press an episode you get a lot of options that could be simplified:

![Screenshot_2013-03-07-16-50-09](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/232777/7ef0850a-8740-11e2-9aaf-15b31a01ae58.png)

In that screenshot:
- "Remove" deletes the file but leaves the episode in the playing queue.
- "Remove from queue" returns the file to the waiting list, but keeps the file in the phone.

If #116 is implemented neither of the above would make sense because being in the queue imply being downloaded, and the other way around. But we do need:
- A "Remove" option that completely deletes the file and makes the app forget about the episode. This should apply to items in the queue, waiting list or history. Also, in addition to a long-press action this could be triggered by swiping the episode away.
- An "Add to queue" option that takes items from the waiting list or the history and adds them to the bottom of the playing queue. Also, of course, sets them to be downloaded ASAP.
- Optionally some "Return to waiting list" and "Move to history" options for items in the queue. I don't think I would want these, though: once you move an episode to the queue you probably won't want to move it back unless you've lost your interest and don't want to listen to it anymore, in which case it would be simpler to just swipe it away and be done with it.
- "Mark as read" removes the "new" banner.
- "Mark as unread" adds it again.

I find these largely irrelevant and, unless I've misunderstood their function, I don't think they're worth two slots in the long-press menu.

Therefore, if you long-press an item in the playing queue I think that you should get these options:
- Play, which moves the episode to the top and starts playing it.
- Remove, already explained.

And if you long-press an item in the waiting list or history you should get:
- Play.
- Remove.
- Add to playing queue, which adds it to the bottom of the queue.

In addition to that, It could be useful to show these options as buttons on the bottom bar so that you can apply them to several items at once. Here's a quick mockup:

![Antennapod](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/233013/00638e92-8747-11e2-8fd0-dd6cf3057409.png)

As you see the mockup shows several selected items and three buttons at the bottom bar, which correspond to Play, Remove and Add to queue.

title: Try a card interface
body:
This suggestion is related to #79 and #116 because it uses a single queue and doesn't distinguish between new and old episodes, but downloaded and undownloaded.

I think that switching to a card interface would make the queue look cleaner and make it easier to delete unwanted episodes:

![Antennapod](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/226933/111fa5a4-8648-11e2-97a1-1d5f7791bdfa.png)

As you see, each episode is separated from the rest and all the relevant data appears in a clean way: you can see the episode's title and channel, as well as duration and progress (except for undownloaded episodes, which show their size instead).

Similarly to #79, the episode being played is shown at the top of the queue. Its card is a bit bigger than the rest and shows some extra data. It also has a bigger proggress bar that lets you scroll through the episode.

As specified in #116 all new episodes are added to the bottom of the "Undownloaded" list. As you listen to the ones at the top they get deleted, making room, and the ones at the top of "Undownloaded" are downloaded and moved to the bottom of the "Downloaded" list, so that you know that you can listen to them without using any mobile data.

You can browse through the whole list and if any particular episodes don't attract you you can simply swipe them away and make room for new ones, which is one of the main benefits of the card interface.

If you're browsing through the Undownloaded episodes and you see one that you like you can long-press it and choose to "Play" it (which moves it to the top of the Downloaded list and starts playing it right away) or "Download" it (which moves it to the bottom of the Downloaded list).

title: Merge "New" and "Queue" tabs for easier use
body:
As a user, I don't really think of "new" episodes as opposed to "queued" ones. I just want to know what new stuff there is to hear, and operate the app while giving it as little thought as possible. I would AntennaPod's interface to reflect this.

I made a quick mockup that you can see here:

![podcast 2](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/23233/8a471234-4a2d-11e2-88f2-5fd28272b456.png)

As you see there's still a "Feeds" tab, but the "New" and "Queued" tabs are replaced by a single "Episodes" one. The episode being played is at the top of it, with some control buttons.

Right below it are the episodes that have been downloaded and are ready to be listened. When the current episode ends, it goes to the History and is replaced by the first item in the list.

Old, listened items are removed automatically and make room for new ones to be downloaded (also automatically) and added to the list.

This way, supposing I have already subscribed to a selection of feeds that I like, I can keep listening to new episodes without ever worrying to check for new episodes, or having to download newer ones or reorder the list, or even ever leaving the "Episodes" screen.

As a user, I would only have to press "Play" to start listening and "Pause" to stop, and no further action would ever be required from me.
